[Music]
the first idea I'd like to suggest is
that we all love music a great deal it
means a lot to us but music is even more
powerful if you don't just listen to it
but you make it yourself so that's my
first idea
and we all know about the Mozart effect
the idea that's been around for the last
5 to 10 years that just by listening to
music or by playing music to your baby
in vitro that it'll raise our uh IQ
points 10 20 30% great idea but it
doesn't work at all so you can't just
listen to music you have to make it
somehow and uh I'd add to that that it's
not just making it but everybody each of
us everybody in the world has the power
to create and be part of Music in a very
Dynamic way and that's one of the main
parts of my work so at the MIT media lab
for quite a while now we've been engaged
in a field called active music what are
all the possible ways that we can think
of to get everybody in the middle of a
musical experience not just listening
but making music and we started by
making instruments for some of the
world's greatest performers we call
these hyper instruments for Yo-Yo Ma
Peter Gabriel Prince orchestra's rock
bands instruments where there're all
kinds of sensors built right into the
instrument so the instrument knows how
it's being played and just by changing
the interpretation and the feeling I can
turn my cello into a voice or into a
whole Orchestra into something never
nobody's ever heard before when we
started making these I started thinking
well why can't we make wonderful
instruments like that for everybody
people who aren't fantastic uh yo-yo Mas
or or princes so we've made a whole
series of instruments one of the largest
collections is called the brain Opera
it's a whole Orchestra of about a 100
instruments all designed for anybody to
play using natural skill so you can play
a video game drive through a piece of
music use your body gesture to control
huge masses of sound a special surface
to make Melodies use your voice to make
a whole Aura and when we make the brain
Opera we invite the public to come in to
try these instruments and then
collaborate with us to help make each
performance of the brain Opera we toured
that for a long time it's now
permanently in Vienna where we built a
museum around it and uh that led to
something which you probably do know
Guitar Hero came out of our lab and my
two teenage daughters and most of the
students at the MIT media lab are proof
that if you make the right kind of
interface people are really interested
in being in the middle of a of a of a
piece of music and playing it over and
over and over again so the model works
but it's only the tip of the iceberg
because my second idea is that it's not
enough just to want to make music in
something like Guitar Hero uh and music
is very fun but it's also transformative
it's very very important music can
change your life more than almost
anything it can change your the way you
communicate with others it can change
your body it can change your mind so we
were trying to go to the next step of
how you build on top of something like
Guitar Hero uh we are very involved in
education have a long term project
called toy Symphony where we make all
kinds of instruments that are also
addictive but for little kids so the
kids will fall in love with making music
want to spend their time doing it and
then will demand to know how it works
how to make more how to create so we
make squeezy instruments like these
music Shapers that measure the
electricity in your fingers beat bugs
that let you tap in rhythms they gather
your Rhythm and like hot potato you send
your Rhythm to your friends who then
have to imitate or respond to what
you're doing and a software package
called hypers score which lets anybody
use line and color to make quite
sophisticated music extremely easy to
use but once you use it you can go quite
deep music in any style and then by
pressing a button it uh turns into uh
music notation so that live musicians
can uh play your pieces we've had good
enough really very powerful effects with
kids around the world and now people of
all ages using hypers score so we've
gotten more and more interested in using
these kind of creat creative activities
in a much broader context for all kinds
of people who don't usually have the
opportunity to make music so one of the
growing fields that we're working on at
the media lab right now is music mind
and health a lot of you have probably
seen Oliver Sax's wonderful new book
called musicophilia It's on sale in the
bookstore it's a great book if you
haven't seen it it's worth reading he's
a Pianist himself and he details his
whole career of looking at and observing
incredibly powerful effects that music
have had on people's lives and unusual
situations so we know for instance that
music is almost always the last thing
that people with Advanced Alzheimer's
can still respond to you maybe many of
you have noticed this with love loved
ones you can find somebody who can't
recognize their face in the mirror can't
tell anyone in their family you can
still find A Shard of music that that
person will jump out of the chair and
start singing and with that you can
bring back parts of people's memories
and personalities music is the best way
to restore speech to people who've lost
it through Strokes movement to people
with Parkinson's disease it's very
powerful for depression schizophrenia
many many things so we're working on
understanding those underlying
principles and then building activities
which will let music really improve
People's Health and we do this in many
ways we work with many differental
hospitals one of them is right near
Boston called tubry hospital it's a
long-term state hospital where several
years ago we started working with hypers
score and patients with physical and
mental disabilities this has become a
central part of the treatment at tubry
hospital so everybody there uh clamors
to work on musical activities it's the
activity that uh seems to accelerate
people's treatment the most and it also
brings the entire Hospital together as a
kind of musical Community I want to show
you a quick video of some of this work
before I go on
sh

manipulating each other's rhythms it's a
real experience not only to learn how to
play and and listen to rhythms but to
train your musical memory and and
playing music in a
group get their hands on music to shape
it themselves to change it to experiment
with it to make their own music so
hypers score lets you start from scratch
very
quickly everybody can experience music
in a profound way we just have to make
different
tools winner really
the third idea I wanted to share with
you is that music paradoxically I think
even more than words it's one of the
very best ways we have of showing who we
really are uh I love giving talks
although Strangely I feel more nervous
giving talks than playing music if I
were here playing cello or playing on a
synth or sharing my music with you I'd
be able to show things about myself that
I can't tell you in words more personal
things perhaps deeper things I think
that's true for for many of us and I
wanted to give you two examples of how
music is is one of the most powerful
interfaces we have from ourselves to the
outside world the first is a really
crazy project that we're building right
now called death in the powers and it's
a big Opera uh one of the larger Opera
projects going on in the world right now
and it's about a man Rich successful
powerful who wants to live forever so he
figures out a way to download himself
into his environment uh actually into a
series of books uh but so this guy wants
to live forever he downloads himself
into his environment the main singer
disappears at the meting of the Opera
and the entire stage becomes the main
character it becomes his legacy and the
Opera is about what we can share what we
can pass on to others to the one people
we love and what we can't every object
in the Opera comes alive and is a
gigantic music instrument like this
chandelier takes up the whole stage
looks like a chandelier but it's
actually a robotic music instrument so
this you can see in this prototype
gigantic piano strings each string is
controlled with a little robotic element
either little bows that stroke the
strings uh propellers that tickle the
strings acoustic signals that vibrate
the strings um we also have an army of
robots on stage uh these robots are the
kind of intermediary between the main
character Simon powers and his family um
there are a whole series of them kind of
like a Greek chorus they observe the
action we've designed these square
robots that we're testing right now at
MIT called Opera Bots these Opera Bots
follow my music they follow the
characters they're smart enough we hope
not to bump into each other they go off
on their own and then they can also when
you snap uh line up exactly the way
you'd like to even though they're cubes
they actually have a lot of
[Music]
personality the largest set piece on the
Opera is it's called the system uh it's
a series of books every single book is
robotic so they all move they all make

which have the gesture and the
personality of Simon Powers so he's
disappeared but the whole phical

um so Todd and I entered into a

and it was really about how Dan is an
expressive person he's an intelligent
and creative person and it's in his face
it's in his breathing it's in his eyes
how come he can't perform one of his
pieces of music that's our
responsibility and it doesn't make sense
so we started developing a technology
that will allow him with Nuance with
Precision with control and despite his

basically first we need an ing solution
so you know we have a FireWire camera it
looks at an infrared pointer we went
with the type of sort of um gesture
metaphor that Dan was already used to
with his talking um with his speaking
controller uh and this is actually the
least interesting part of the work you

input we needed continuous tracking in
the software we look at the types of
shapes he's making um but then was the
really interesting aspect of the work uh
following the engineering part where
basically we were coding over Dan's
shoulder at the hospital extensively to
figure out you know how does Dan move
what's useful to him as an expressive
motion you know what's his metaphor of
performance what types of things does he
find important to control and convey in
a piece of music and so all the
parameter fitting and really the
technology was stretched at that point
to fit just Dan and you know I think
this is a a a perspective shift it's not
that our
Technologies they provide access they
allow us to create pieces of creative
work but what about expression what
about that moment when an artist deliver
that piece of work you know do our
Technologies allow us to express do they
provide structure for us to do that and
you know that's a personal relationship
to expression um that is lacking in the
technological sphere so you know with
Dan we needed a new design process a new
Engineering Process to sort of discover
his movement and his path to expression
that allow him to perform and so that's
